texts.shortText:
Stauromedusae are a small group of sedentary medusae that are attached ‘upside-down’ to the substratum by an adhesive disc. From the basal disc arises a stalk that spreads out into an umbrella-like oral disc with a central mouth encircled by short arms, which bear clusters of small, knobbed tentacles. There are only about 50 described species worldwide and only 4 in South Africa.

This species can be white, orange or green and is elongate and tubular with the gonads showing as double rows of paler bulges along the column. Distally 8 short arms are armed with knobbed tentacles.
Up to about 20 mm in height when extended.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.  Previously published records from Australia and New Zealand are now thought to represent a distinct species.

Local/Regional: Hondeklip Bay on west coast to Hermanus.

This little-known but interesting upside-down jellyfish is known from relatively few published records, but once one knows where to look for it, it is in fact quite easy to find and common. Best found attached to large seaweeds in sheltered pools and usually occurs singly, the body colour usually matching that of the host alga. Can relocate by detaching and somersaulting and is predatory, feeding on small invertebrates that stumble into the tentacles.
Feeds on small crustaceans, especially copepods and ostracods, and other invertebrates that live on the surfaces of algae.

Unlike most jellyfish Stauromedusae do not have an alternating polyp and medusa lifecycle. Sexually mature medusae release sperm and eggs into the water, which merge to form creeping planula larvae that settle and develop directly into new attached Stauromedusae.

By far the most common stauromedusa in the region but can be confused with two rarer species of the related genus Calvadosia that also occur in the region.

The first of these, C. lewisi, was only described in 2017, and has a much shorter column and 4 arms that are divided near their tips and are held out horizontally like a cross. It occurs on kelps and other large algae in the Western Cape.

Another species, C. capensis is known from just a single South African specimen collected from Sargassum in an intertidal rockpool near East London in the 1930s, and has subsequently been recorded from just one other individual collected in Brazil! It is upright and has pad-like adhesive structures at the base of the arms beneath the tentacles. Probably it is widely distributed, but often confused with D. africana and it would be exciting to rediscover this species and determine its true distribution.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 50).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 50).

Miranda, LS, Branch, GM, Collins, AG, Hirano, YM, Marques, AC & Griffiths, CL (2017). Stalked jellyfishes (Cnidaria: Staurozoa) of South Africa, with the description of Calvadosia lewisi sp nov. Zootaxa, 4227(3), 369-389.
